dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NORMA LEWIS (31) sits up in bed. The soft glow of the lam casts her in silhouette. Her husband, ARTHUR LEWIS (30), next to her.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: Did you hear something?

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: The doorbell.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: Are you sure that was the doorbell? From down below... the DOORBELL rings again.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: Yep. Norma retrieves her WATCH from the bedside table.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What time is it?

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: Quarter ‘til five. Norma gets out of bed and throws on her bathrobe. Arthur sits up, hair sticking up in every direction. He h sideburns that run down the side of his face like daggers

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norma comes down the stairs and approaches the front door She looks through the PEEPHOLE. Through the PEEPHOLE... she glimpses a BLACK SEDAN idling the street. It quickly drives off. Norma unlatches the DEAD BOLT and opens the door. She not something at her feet.  Someone has left a CARDBOARD BOX on the front step. It's dimensions are 1’ x 1’ xl’. She leans down and picks up the box, noticing that it has been meticulously sealed with clear tape. There are no markings on it whatsoever. Norma looks down the quiet, empty street. She quickly clo the door and turns inside and away from the cold air. Arthur arrives at the bottom of the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: What is it?

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: Someone left a box.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: I don't know. There was a car waiting... but they drove off. Norma hands the box to Arthur. He examines it.

dialogues.speaker: MALE VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Is that one of my Christmas presents? Their young son, WALTER LEWIS (9), is standing at the top the stairs. He is dressed in his pajamas. His parents just stare back at him in silence.

dialogues.speaker: INT, LEWIS HOUSE
dialogues.text: The Lewis family has now moved into the kitchen. WRAPPING PAPER and CHRISTMAS ORNAMENTS are scattered across the ta Norma is pouring COFFEE. Arthur is cutting through the ta that seals the box with a knife while Walter looks on eagerly.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: Should I close my eyes?

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: Maybe... it’s up to you. Arthur opens the lid and sees that there are FOAM PEANUTS inside. He digs down and retrieves a WOODEN BOX. Its dimensions are 8” x 8” x 8”. The box is made of WHITE ORK with a clear varnish. Mount top is a CLEAR GLASS DOME attached to a lid with a HINGE MOUNT. Inside of the dome is a CYLINDRICAL METAL BUTTON.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: Is there a note? Arthur reaches inside the box and retrieves a_ small WHIT ENVELOPE. Printed on the envelope in CALLIGRAPHY is the n

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: It's for you, Norma. Norma opens the envelope and removes a folded piece of wh stationary. Printed in elegant calligraphy is a single sentence: MR. STEWARD WILL CALL UPON YOU AT O PM.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: Mr. Steward will call upon you at 5 PM. (to herself) Do I know a Mr. Steward? Arthur yawns.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: I dunno. You tell us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur is now showered and shaven, dressed for work. He a Walter sit at the kitchen table, waiting for Norma to del breakfast. The box sits on the table between them. Arthur opens up the newspaper.

dialogues.speaker: OPEC SAID TO DECIDE ON SPLIT HIKE
dialogues.text: Arthur turns the page.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What kind of car was it?

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: Z couldn't see. It was dark and T didn't have my contacts in.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: Why would they just drive off?

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: I don’t know. But the bus will be here if five minutes... so eat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norma and Walter emerge from the house onto the front por She hands him his LUNCH BOX and a WINTER HAT. SNOW has be to fall from the sky.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: Last day of school and now it starts to snow?!

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: Put on your hat... A young girl, DANA (13) is waiting at the end of the sidewalk. She is wrapped head-to-toe in warm clothes... EARMUFFS and SCARF around her neck.

dialogues.speaker: DANA
dialogues.text: (muffled through scarf) Hi Mrs. Lewis.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: Good morning, Dana. (shivering) And please call me Norma. You're making me feel old.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: You are old!

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: I’m thirty-one!

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: To us that's old! You’re a geezer!

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: Well you'll be a geezer one day too, smarty-pants.  Norma closes her eyes, taking in a breath of cold air. Snowflakes land in her face and hair. Walter sighs... looking at his watch.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: Why does the bus stop have to be at the end of our driveway?

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: (high-pitched) So I can watch my little Walter get on his bus... safe in one piece! Down the street, A SCHOOL BUS begins to crest the hill... fast approaching...

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: Please. Go. Inside. You’re embarrassing me.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: My love embarrasses you?

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: Yes. Yes it does. She begins to walk down the sidewalk... taunting him as t bus approaches.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: What if I give little Walter a little kiss in front of all his friends on the school bus? Dana’s eyes widen. A MISCHIEVOUS GRIN emerges from behind scarf that covers the lower part of her face.

dialogues.speaker: DANA
dialogues.text: Do it! The bus is fast approaching... brakes squealing as it slo to a stop.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: Don't come any closer! Norma gives him a big HUG and a KISS right as the bus doo open. A bunch of OLDER KIDS stare out the window... scowl at him. Walter pushes away from her and stomps up onto the bus... mortified. Dana follows him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dana... you're baby-sitting for us tonight, right?

dialogues.speaker: DANA
dialogues.text: Eight o'clock?

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: Eight o'clock.

dialogues.speaker: DANA
dialogues.text: Okay. Dana gets on the bus. BUD WALL (30s), the bus driver, smi at Norma. He is an enormous giant of a man with a shaved head.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: Bus-Driver Bud! Merry Christmas...

dialogues.speaker: BUD
dialogues.text: Our last day!

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: I know!

dialogues.speaker: BUD
dialogues.text: It‘ll all be over soon, Norma. He stares at her for a moment that is almost too long... shuts the doors to the bus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur sits at the table... reading the morning paper. The CAMERA zooms into the COMICS SECTION... revealing the panels of the comic strip REX MORGAN, MD. Arthur begins reading the voices of REX MORGAN and his girlfriend JUNE.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: (as Rex Morgan) Do you realize that this is the first time in my life that I will be taking more than a week's vacation, June? Norma arrives in the kitchen. She now has a slight limp.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: {as June, hi-pitched) And enjoy it! Don't worry about the office!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rex Morgan... I need you back here no later than seven. Rehearsal dinner starts at eight. Arthur grabs his BRIEFCASE and a BASKETBALL.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: The Viking Squad has a game at four.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: Don't get stuck in Friday traffic...

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: Okay June. He starts bouncing the ball on the kitchen floor. She grabs the ball in mid bounce... annoyed with him.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: Not in the house!

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: How’s your foot?

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: It's fine. She pushes him toward into the FAMILY ROOM...- opening th door that leads out to the garage. They exit the house and the CAMERA drifts back toward the kitchen table... moving in toward the box.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The GARAGE DOOR opens and both of the LEWIS FAMILY CARS b out at the same time, almost choreographed in perfect uni Arthur drives a SILVER 1975 PONTIAC TRANS-AM. Norma drive WHITE 1976 OLDSMOBILE STATION WAGON with WOOD WALLS. They pull out onto MONUMENT AVENUE, cars pointing in oppo directions. Arthur rolls down his window.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: It’s your Christmas present.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: From you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From your secret lover. (beat) Mr. Steward. She furrows her brow.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: (sarcastic) I hate you, Rex Morgan MD.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: (playful) I hate you, too.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: Don’t be late tonicht.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: I've got your present at work. It’s almost finished. He smiles... then peels off down Monument Ave. From Norma’s REAR VIEW MIRROR... Arthur's car disappears the road. She reaches up to re-adjust... her eyes appear the mirror's reflection. INSERT: Norma’s VIRGINIA license plate. The Oldsmobile drives down the street in the opposite direction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HELICOPTER SHOT: The CAMERA crests over the barren WINTER FOREST on the southeast side of the city... tipping up to reveal DOWNTOWN RICHMOND, VIRGINIA.

dialogues.speaker: RADIO VOICE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: It's twenty-three degrees on this December morning here in Richmond... The CAMERA moves over the DOWNTOWN EXPRESSWAY... heavy traffic moves in either direction. The CAMERA approaches the side of ARTHUR’S TRANS-AM as it crests around the INTERSTATE EXCHANGE onto ROUTE 64 at th HISTORICAL CLOCK TOWER of MAIN STREET TRAIN STATION.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The French government, in what was seen here as a gesture to President— elect Jimmy Carter, announced Thursday a further tightening of controls over the exportation of nuclear technology. The CAMERA swoops down alongside the driver's side of Arthur’s car... moving into the SIDE VIEW MIRROR. His fac reflected in the mirror... listening to the radio as he begins his southbound commute to work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The CAMERA pulls back from a sign at the entrance to COLLEGIATE... an exclusive PRIVATE SCHOOL. Norma’s STATIO WAGON pulls into the school parking lot.

dialogues.speaker: INT, COLLEGIATE SCHOOL -
dialogues.text: The CAMERA tracks with Norma as makes her way through the CROWDED HALLWAY... filled with LOUD TEENAGERS from the ag 9-18. Her limp. has gotten worse. She WINKS at someone... then turns a corner and the CAMER whips around to reveal WALTER standing at his locker. He closes the door, revealing Dana and another friend named CHARLES (12) standing there.

dialogues.speaker: DANA
dialogues.text: Why does your mom limp?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLES
dialogues.text: Yeah... is something wrong with her foot?

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: That's none of your business.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLES
dialogues.text: Dana saw her take her shoe off in the parking lot yesterday.

dialogues.speaker: DANA
dialogues.text: There’s definitely something wrong with her foot. It looks mangled.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLES
dialogues.text: You didn’t say mangled... you said it looked gross. Walter lunges at Charles and pushes him up against the locker... awkwardly trying to fight him.  10. They continue to wrestle awkwardly for a moment against t lockers and then Walter lets go... backing away.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: If you ever make fun of my mom again I‘ll kill you! Walter storms off down the hall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The CAMERA moves through the SCHOOL OFFICE as teachers an RECEPTIONISTS move about in preparation for the last day, approaching a FROSTED GLASS DOOR that reads:

dialogues.speaker: DR. WILLIAM H. POATES
dialogues.text: INT. COLLEGIATE SCHOOL -- PRINCIPAL’S OFFICE -- NEXT Norma sits across from the desk of WILLIAM POATES (45), t principal of the school.

dialogues.speaker: POATES
dialogues.text: The uhhh... the board came to a vote last week, so it’s official. They've officially cancelled the faculty tuition discount.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: So what does that mean for me?

dialogues.speaker: POATES
dialogues.text: You're going to have to start paying full tuition for your son.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: Starting when?

dialogues.speaker: POATES
dialogues.text: Next semester. Norma notices a SMALL DROP of BLOOD forming in his right nostril.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: POATES
dialogues.text: I’m real sorry about this, Norma.  ii.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: Yeah, me too. I've got three weeks to figure out how to tell my son we can't afford to send him to Collegiate any more. The drop of blood has begun to flow down onto his upper l

dialogues.speaker: POATES
dialogues.text: Like I said, I’m real sorry.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: Yeah... your nose is bleeding. Poates reaches for his HANDKERCHIEF and puts it to his fa wiping off the blood. The MORNING BELL rings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norma walks hurriedly down the empty hallway. Her limp ha gotten worse as the morning grind has now begun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norma comes into her CLASSROOM... a SCIENCE LAB with SINK and BUNSEN BURNERS mounted in MARBLE TOP DESKS. Kids are moving about... loud and rambunctious.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: Okay... everyone quiet down! Take your seats! Norma moves toward a stack of METAL TRAYS on her desk. In of each tray is a BALL OF BLACK MUSH.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Today is the day many of you have been eagerly awaiting. You get to dissect owl pellets. A MALE STUDENT (13) pumps his fist...

dialogues.speaker: MALE STUDENT
dialogues.text: Yes! Norma sets an OWL PELLET down in front of a FEMALE STUDEN (12). She looks at the owl pellet in disgust.

dialogues.speaker: FEMALE STUDENT
dialogues.text: This is so gross. Norma sets a tray down in front of Charles.  12.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLES
dialogues.text: Why do they call it an owl pellet? A MALE STUDENT (12) next to him takes his tray from Norma

dialogues.speaker: MALE STUCENT
dialogues.text: Because they shit out of their mouths.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: Hey... watch the language. You say another cuss word I’ve gotta send you to detention, okay?

dialogues.speaker: MALE STUDENT
dialogues.text: Sorry, Mrs. Lewis.

dialogues.speaker: FEMALE STUDENT
dialogues.text: Is it true?

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: Is what true?

dialogues.speaker: FEMALE STUDENT
dialogues.text: That owls poo out of their mouths.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: Yes... this is true. The classroom gasps in disgust... others laugh.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Grey forest owls feed upon field mice, squirrels and small birds. The owl will then regurgitate the bones and waste matter in a ball of black mucous. Inside this mucous you will likely find the entire skeleton of its prey. Norma goes to the front of the room and lowers a SCREEN.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I'm going to show you a film about the digestive process of the owl, and how the owl pellet is formed. The classroom whispers with excitement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur pulls through the ENTRANCE GATE at the NASA LANGLE RESEARCH CENTER. He retrieves his BADGE from the dashboar and shows it to the guard.  oo 13.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur's car drives down MAIN STREET on the campus of the research center. The buildings are predominately drab, functional, one story brick structures.. surrounded by Yarious GLOBE STRUCTURES and PIPE NETWORKS on manicured g lawns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The CAMERA tracks with Arthur as he moves through the cro corridor of one of the research buildings. He says hello various colleagues along the way. All of the men at the facility are dressed the same... wi white shirts and TIES and POCKET PROTECTOR BADGES. The pl resembles an all-male community college for young scienti

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur eases his way into the small, crowded AUDITORIUM t serves as a MEDIA ROOM. A PRESS CONFERENCE is underway. NORM CAHILL (40s), the VIKING PROJECT COORDINATOR, is standing at the podium. Next to him is an OVERHEAD PROJEC with maps and various schematics projected from it onto a LARGE SCREEN.

dialogues.speaker: REPORTER
dialogues.text: It’s been five months since the Viking lander touched down on the surface of Mars. We've seen dozens of photographs of the rock covered surface... what can you now tell us about the tests you’ve been conducting? Is there any sign of life on the red planet? Arthur takes a seat in the back of the auditorium. y

dialogues.speaker: CAHILL
dialogues.text: Well... there are three separate tests that we’ve been conducting... Pyrolytic Release, Labeled Release and Gas Exchange. The first two tests, based on soil samples about 22 centimeters deep, came back negative... and the third is... still pending. Cahill smiles. Laughter erupts from various parts of the auditorium.  14.

dialogues.speaker: REPORTER
dialogues.text: Can you elaborate on test number three? Cahill places a transparent MAP of the mars surface on th overhead projector and begins to draw on it with a WAX PENCIL.

dialogues.speaker: CAHILL
dialogues.text: The gas exchange experiment measures the production or uptake of C02, nitrogen, methane, hydrogen, and oxygen during the incubation of the martian soil sample.

dialogues.speaker: REPORTER
dialogues.text: Are you showing us all of the photos? Are there little green men up there? Laughter from the press.

dialogues.speaker: CAHILL
dialogues.text: Well... there is a possibility that the planet abounds with chemical compounds produced by living systems. Their chemical nature, distribution and structural uniqueness could be used to argue the presence of microscopic living organisms on Mars. As Cahill moves on to the next question... Arthur taps th reporter on the shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: It all comes down to water. Arthur points to an OVERHEAD SATELLITE PHOTO of Utopia Planitia, a raised level of martian terrain in the vicini of the site where VIKING II landed. There are dry river-bed formations in the soil.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Tf we find water beneath the surface... and the topographic maps of Utopia Planitia indicate that there were once rivers on the surface of the planet, it’s possible that we‘ll eventually find evidence of life.  15.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The OWL PELLET FILM is underway. Norma sits in the back o the class next to the projector. She crosses her legs... reaching for her foot... massaging it gently. She cringes clearly in intense pain. Charles looks back at her... noticing this. They make eye contact... and Charles turns back to the screen. INT. NASA LANGLEY FACILITY -- CAHILL’S OFFICE -- MORNING Arthur now sits across from Cahill in his office. Behind is a window that overlooks a huge laboratory.

dialogues.speaker: CAHILL
dialogues.text: I’m sorry Arthur, but they’ve denied your application to be admitted into the astronaut program. Arthur looks crushed.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: I see. (beat) Can I ask why?

dialogues.speaker: CAHILL
dialogues.text: I’m sorry, son... but they don’t tell us why.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The CAMERA tracks through a LARGE LABORATORY in the heart one of the main buildings on the Langley campus. Work tables assembled with LABORATORY EQUIPMENT and MACHI extend out into infinity as DOZENS OF YOUNG MEN, all dres in similar white shirts with NASA ID BADGES move througho engaged in various tasks. Arthur is standing at a LABORATORY TABLE with a WHITE MAS on. He is wearing a LAB COAT and GLASSES. He pours PINK LIQUID onto the surface of a METAL PAN... filling it to the edges. A colleague named WENDELL JAMES (29) walks over to see wh he is doing.  16.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: Are they really with-holding some of the Mars photos?

dialogues.speaker: WENDELL
dialogues.text: I don't know, man. Jesus... what’s that smell?

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: It's a salinic compound.

dialogues.speaker: WENDELL
dialogues.text: What are you making?

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: Christmas present for Norma. Arthur retrieves a WHITE CERAMIC MOLD. The mold has an extrusion that is shaped like a WOMAN’S FOOT... only the of the foot is round and missing its toes, save for the P TOE.

dialogues.speaker: WENDELL
dialogues.text: A new prosthesis for her foot?

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: Yep. Arthur carefully impresses the MOLD of his wife's foot in the pink goop... sealing the mold at the edges into the t

dialogues.speaker: WENDELL
dialogues.text: What did you change up this time?

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: The compound they’re developing for the pilot chairs on the space shuttle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INSERT: The BONES of a FIELD MOUSE have been re-assembled rough form within the tray... as the OWL PELLET has been ripped apart. The tray belongs to Charles, and he has grown tired of dissecting the owl pellet. He looks up to the head of the class and sees that Norma sitting up on her desk... filing her nails... waiting out last remaining minutes of the period.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLES
dialogues.text: Mrs. Lewis?  17. She raises her head.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: Hmmm?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLES
dialogues.text: What happened to your foot? She just stares at him.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: What happened... to my foot?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLES
dialogues.text: Yeah. (beat) My friend... she saw you take your shoe off. She said... that there's something wrong with it. The whole class goes silent. Norma begins to blush. She l down at her right foot, hidden inside of a CLOSED-TOE SHO

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: Well... it’s a long story. She looks at her watch.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We've got five minutes until second period. She looks back at her class and sees that their curiosity been piqued. She has no choice now but to tell them.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Alright... I’11 tell you what happened to my foot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur sits at the table with Wendell... waiting for the to dry. Arthur is dealing a deck of cards as they begin a game of GIN RUMMY.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: When she was seventeen... still living in Texas, her brother dropped a barbell on her foot... broke three of her toes.  18.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The CAMERA pans across the faces of STUDENTS as they list to her tell the story.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: And so I go to see the doctor. He goes to take an X-ray of my foot to see if the bones are broken.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur discards... then retrieves a replacement card from stack.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: So this dumb-ass Richmond doctor takes the x-ray... then he goes to check on another patient down the hall. Arthur discards a king.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: This dumb-ass... he left the x-ray machine on.

dialogues.speaker: WENDELL
dialogues.text: Jesus. That’s not good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norma raises up her right shoe to show the class. NORMA. They found out that the tissue in four of my toes had been completely destroyed by the radiation. Norma swivels around on the desk and places her right foo against her left inner thigh.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So they have to amputate four of my toes. And then they had to take a bunch of skin from my inner thigh to cover the front of my foot. This is back in 1963... so they didn't have the skin graft techniques they do now.  19.

dialogues.speaker: INT, NASA LANGLEY FACILITY
dialogues.text: Arthur stands up and takes his RIGHT FOOT... pulls it up touches it to his LEFT INNER THIGH.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: She had to sit there in a hospital bed in the same position for six months, waiting for it to heal. Wendell stares at the mold on the laboratory table.

dialogues.speaker: WENDELL
dialogues.text: Jesus. I hope she sued this idiot.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: Oh yeah. Her family sued. They won.

dialogues.speaker: WENDELL
dialogues.text: What was the settlement?

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: Forty thousand dollars. Arthur pulls the ceramic mold out of the pink goop... and see the IMPRESSION of her disfigured foot inside the new PROSTHESIS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norma turns around and uncrosses her legs. They now dangl over the edge of the lab desk.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: You guys want to see it? Now that the secret is out... I don’t want you spreading rumors about my mangled foot. The class responds enthusiastically.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Come on... gather round... take a look at the freak show. As the kids gather around... Norma removes her right shoe reveals her disfigured foot... missing every toe but her pinky. A rounded piece of SCAR TISSUE covers the rest of  20.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur takes the trimmed PROSTHESIS and wraps it in tissu paper, then places it in a CARDBOARD BOX with a red bow o it.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: If this sucker works... she can start jogging again. :

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dana walks up to Walter as he stands in front of his lock

dialogues.speaker: DANA
dialogues.text: I’m sorry I said that her foot looked gross.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: It doesn’t look gross... it looks cool. And if you can’t tell the difference between gross and cool... then I feel sorry for you, Dana. Walter walks off... leaving her alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norma emerges from her car carrying GROCERY BAGS in both arms. Walter comes out of the garage with his bike.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: Hey honey.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: Why do I need a baby-sitter?

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: Because you're nine years old. You’re not a geezer yet.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: It's 1976, mom. Times are changing. Nine years old isn't what it used to be. I think I’m ready to get a moped.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: We're not buying you a moped, Walter. Stick with the bike... and be home before dark.  2l.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: Fine. Walter rides off down the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norma comes into the foyer, groceries in hand. The PHONE ringing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norma comes into the kitchen, sets the groceries down on kitchen table. She grabs the phone off the wall and puts to her ear.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: Hello? There is silence on the other end of the line.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hello? A MOMENT OF SILENCE... then the caller disconnects. Norma hangs up the phone and starts unloading the groceri The box sits on the table... but she takes no notice of i

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur emerges from a NASA CAMPUS GYMNASIUM into the twil with Wendell. Both are covered in sweat, dressed in gym clothes. Arthur is carrying his BASKETBALL and a gym bag.

dialogues.speaker: WENDELL
dialogues.text: How's the commute back to Richmond?

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: Not too bad. Maybe an hour and twenty minutes.

dialogues.speaker: WENDELL
dialogues.text: Tell Norma I said hello. Wendell watches him walk across the lawn to the parking lot... approaching his car. He lights a cigarette and tak drag... then looks at his watch. INSERT: His watch shows that it is 4:58 PM.  22.

dialogues.speaker: INT, LEWIS HOUSE
dialogues.text: Norma sits on the couch... smoking a CIGARETTE. On the TELEVISION... the LOCAL NEWS is playing. The DOORBELL rings.

dialogues.speaker: INT, LEWIS HOUSE
dialogues.text: Norma opens the front door. A man named ARLINGTON STEWARD (40) is standing there, his body is turned in profile. He is wearing a crisp wool sui and a BLACK HAT, with a BRIEFCASE in his right hand.

dialogues.speaker: ARLINGTON
dialogues.text: Mrs. Lewis?

dialogues.speaker: NORMA,
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: ARLINGTON
dialogues.text: My name is Arlington Steward. Her eyes light up, as she remembers the name and the box. Arlington then rotates his body... revealing the RIGHT SI of his face. Norma's eyes widen in horror at what she see Nearly all of the right side of his face from his cheekbo to his lower jaw has been burned away. His rear MOLARS an GUMS are exposed beneath the absence of tissue that is supposed to conceal them. Norma immediately feels a strange connection... a deep sympathy for him and the pain he must have endured.

dialogues.speaker: ARLINGTON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I assume you received the box that I left on your doorstep. His speech has a slight impediment from the burn that ext to the right side of his mouth.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: Oh, yes. Yes we did.

dialogues.speaker: ARLINGTON
dialogues.text: And you retrieved the button unit inside of the box. Norma smiles. He smiles back at her.  23.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: The button unit. That‘’s what you call it?

dialogues.speaker: ARLINGTON
dialogues.text: Indeed. May I come in?

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: Sure. Norma turns and leads him back into the kitchen. She retrieves the button unit from the table.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So what it this thing? I assume you're trying to sell me something?

dialogues.speaker: ARLINGTON
dialogues.text: Well... in a way, yes. I do have an offer to make.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: Yeah? What are you selling?

dialogues.speaker: ARLINGTON
dialogues.text: A financial opportunity. ‘Arlington gestures toward the table with his briefcase.

dialogues.speaker: ARLINGTON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: May I? She nods. He places the briefcase down on the table. He takes the button unit from her and sets it down on the kitchen table. They both sit down. He then withdraws a SMALL YELLOW ENVELOPE from his suit jacket pocket.

dialogues.speaker: ARLINGTON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Inside of this envelope is a key. Arlington opens the envelope and withdraws a small METAL

dialogues.speaker: ARLINGTON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: This is the key that opens the glass dome of the button unit. Arlington then inserts the key into a small HORIZONTAL SL at the top edge. He turns the key, and the LID that house the GLASS DOME pops lose. The METAL BUTTON is now exposed.  24.

dialogues.speaker: ARLINGTON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: If you push the button, one of two things will happen. (beat) First, someone... somewhere in the world... who you do not know... will die. Norma just stares at him.

dialogues.speaker: ARLINGTON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Then, you will receive a payment of two-hundred thousand dollars... tax free. Arlington opens the briefcase. Inside are neatly stacked of ONE-HUNDRED DOLLAR BILLS.

dialogues.speaker: ARLINGTON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The money will be delivered to you in cash. Norma covers her mouth... shocked at the sight of so much money. NORMA. Are you for real? Arlington smiles back at her.

dialogues.speaker: ARLINGTON
dialogues.text: Mrs. Lewis, I can assure you that the offer is real.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: Who do you work for?

dialogues.speaker: ARLINGTON
dialogues.text: The guarantee of payment has several restrictions. One... I am not permitted to disclose any information about to the identity of my employers. (beat) Two... if you discuss the details of this financial opportunity with anyone other than your husband, the offer is null and void, and you will not receive the money in return for having pushed the button. (beat) Three... you have twenty four hours. Arlington glances at his watch.  25.

dialogues.speaker: ARLINGTON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You have until five o'clock tomorrow evening to make your decision whether or not to push the button. At that time, I will return to retrieve the button unit from you. It will be re-programmed and the offer will be made to someone else. Arlington places the key back into the envelope, seals it with crisp precision, and hands it over to her. He then closes the briefcase and stands up to leave.

dialogues.speaker: ARLINGTON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Until then... a good day to you, Mrs. Lewis. He nods his head and turns toward the foyer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She follows him toward the front door.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: Wait a minute... you're just going to leave me with this thing. (baffled) Is this some kind of joke? Who are you? He opens the front door and turns back to her with a frie smile.

dialogues.speaker: ARLINGTON
dialogues.text: My name is Arlington Steward, and I can assure you that this is no joke. The offer is real, but I am not at liberty to disclose any more information than I already have. He withdraws a BUSINESS CARD and hands it to her.

dialogues.speaker: ARLINGTON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Good day. He heads down the walk towarc his car. She looks down at the card and sees that his name is prin in an embossed BLACK FONT:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She turns the card over and sees what looks like a PHONE NUMBER printed on the back: 8047941779 She stands there in the doorway and watches him step into automobile, start the engine and drive off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter is sitting on a bench in front of a line of shops CARYTOWN. Dana approaches him. He turns to face her.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: What do you want?

dialogues.speaker: DANA
dialogues.text: I’m sorry. I just wanted to tell you... that I think your mom is beautiful. Walter just stares at her in silence... wanting to forgiv her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norma walks back into the kitchen, holding the key envelo in one hand and the business card in the other. She stares at them both, then down at the box. She then retrieves the key from the envelope and inserts it into t slot, opening the glass dome. She stares at the button for a long moment... then closes dome. She closes her eyes... crying to make sense of what just transpired.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The CAMERA zooms out from a RINGING PHONE that sits on a KITCHEN COUNTER in a large suburban house. SUSAN BURNS (5 goes to answer the phone.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Hello?

dialogues.speaker: NORMA, (PHONE)
dialogues.text: Hey mom.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Hey honey. What's up?  27.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA, (PHONE)
dialogues.text: Nothing... I just... The CAMERA continues to zoom out, revealing her husband, BURNS (50s) laid out in a recliner, watching television.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Is something wrong?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norma stares at the business card.

dialogues.speaker: . NORMA
dialogues.text: No... something just happened and...

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN, (PHONE)
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: Nothing. I don’t want to talk about it right now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Susan carries the phone into the family room

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Alright. (covering the phone) Jim... you gotta get ready.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: Alright. He sits up and moves toward the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Wait until you see the spread tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norma twirls the phone cord around her finger.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: Hmmm. I think they're spending more on their wedding than we did on our house.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN, (PHONE)
dialogues.text: Is your foot acting up again?  28. Norma leans against the wall... Lifting her right foot of the floor to ease the pain,

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: A little, yeah. That damn bone. The skin from my leg, it’s not as tough as it should be.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN, (PHONE)
dialogues.text: You know he's gonna be there tonight. NORMA. Who?

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Dr. Stupid. Norma takes this in... remembering...

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: Well... it’s been what... thirteen years? Bound to run into each other at some point, right? INT. LEWIS HOUSE -- MASTER BATHROOM -— LATER ON Norma is now wearing only her BRA AND PANTIES, her hair a make-up flawless. She finishes putting on a pair of DIAMO EARRINGS . As she steps into an elegant COCKTAIL DRESS... we see the deep square shaped SCARS on the inside of her LEFT THIGH. INT. LEWIS HOUSE -- MASTER BEDROOM -— NEXT Norma comes into the bedroom... and ARTHUR is there... putting on his CUFF LINKS. He is dressed in a TUXEDO. His jacket is laid out on the bed, and next to it is his CHRISTMAS PRESENT. Norma sees it.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA,
dialogues.text: What's this?

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: A little gift from Dr. Rex Morgan. She opens the present and retrieves the PROSTHESIS.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: Oh my god!  29. Norma removes an old, store-bought INSOLE from her right and inserts the new one.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: It's a material they developed for the new shuttle chairs. It’ll absorb the pressure of your foot and re-distribute it across the entire surface areé. She then slides her disfigured foot into the shoe... and begins to walk around the room.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: Oh my God, Rex... how’d you do it?

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: I just figured out a way to make it better. She crosses the room and gives him a hug and a kiss.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: I don’t know what I'd do without you.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: Merry Christmas, June.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norma and Arthur come into the family room, wearing their winter coats. Walter is sitting across the coffee table w Dana. They are playing CARDS. The box is sitting between them.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: Did Mr. Steward show up? Norma sees the box sitting there and immediately grabs it the table.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: Yeah... what's it all about. Did he show up?

dialogues.speaker: NORMA,
dialogues.text: Yeah... I'1]1 tell you about it in the car. We're running late. Norma leans down and kisses Walter on the cheek.  30.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We'll be home late... your bedtime is ten. Dana watches them go... her eyes transfixed on the box in Norma's hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The CAMERA tracks with Arthur’s car as it drives south on CARY STREET... approaching an intersection. INT. ARTHUR’S CAR -- NEXT Norma has the box sitting in her lap while Arthur drives.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: And before I could ask him anything else... he got in his car... and he pulled off. ARTHUR . Did you get the license plate?

dialogues.speaker: NORMA,
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: Your dad is cop, Norma. Always get the license plate number.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: I was little overwhelmed, Arthur.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: Somewhere in the world... someone you do not know will die.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: Those were his exact words.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: Did he say how they would die?

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: And he showed you the cash.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: Yeah. He said it was two-hundred thousand. It looked real to me.  31.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: What did he look Like? NORMA. You don’t want to know. I think he’s a burn victim. Poor thing... half of his face is gone.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: Really? NORMA. I think maybe he’s a life insurance salesman. Maybe that’s what it is. It’s some kind of survey. We push the button and he offers us a discount on a two-hundred thousand dollar life insurance policy. Joke’s on us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The CAMERA descends upon the COUNTRY CLUB OF VIRGINIA. It a MASSIVE COLONIAL MANSION that sits upon a huge hill tha littered with CHRISTMAS LUMINARIES that glow in the night

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We approach Arthur’s car as they pull into a PARKING SPAC front of the main entrance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur grabs the box from off her lap.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: Did you bring the key with you? She hands it to him. He takes the key and inserts it... opening the glass dome He then takes his INDEX FINGER and places it on the butto

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: What the hell are you doing?!

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: (playful) I was gonna push the button.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: Not  32. Norma reaches over and snaps the dome closed.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: you think it’s for real. She takes the box back from him,

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: I don’t know. He was... he seemed very sure of himself. If it’s some kind of survey... then... he’s a really good salesman because I believe him. I believe that he might give us that money.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: Do then you think he’s a maniac and he might go kill someone?

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: I don’t know. Arthur takes the box back from her, He shakes it... then flips it over. He sees that there is a SINGLE SCREW on th bottom corner that holds it together.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: Open the glove compartment. There’s a philips head screwdriver in there. She opens the GLOVE COMPARTMENT and retrieves a PHILLIPS SCREWDRIVER for him.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: What are you doing? Arthur is now unscrewing the bottom of the box.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: I’m gonna see what’s inside of it. He removes the screw... and sees that the wooden base rot on a ROD MOUNT on the opposite corner. INSIDE... it is completely empty.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Nothing... no transmitter... no radio. If we pushed the button right now... he’d have no way of knowing. She takes the box from him and closes the dome.  33.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur pops open the trunk and Norma places the box insid He shuts the trunk and they begin to walk toward the entr to the COUNTRY CLUB. Arthur then holds out his hand to hi wife.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: Let me hold the key.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: Why do you get to hold it?

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: Because you’ll lose it Norma. You can’t hold your liquor.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: Neither can you.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: What if someone takes your purse? I have pockets. Let me hold it.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: Fine. Norma goes through her purse and hands the small envelope him. They move toward the entrance to the country club.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The CAMERA follows Norma and Arthur into the GRAND BALLRO of the country club. There are several hundred people there... all dressed in black tie. A MASSIVE CHRISTMAS TR sits in the center of the room, surrounded by tables. A PIANO PLAYER plays CHRISTMAS CAROLS up on the stage.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: Jesus. All this for a rehearsal dinner... Deborah is so lucky. Remember our rehearsal dinner?

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: Yeah. Keg party in our back yard. Susan and Jim are standing with ARTHUR LEWIS, SR (50s) an BEV LEWIS (50s). Arthur and Norma go over to greet them. The CAMERA drifts over to a PLACARD that reads:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RE S. DINNER CEP. Ne

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dana enters the family room and hands a package to Walter

dialogues.speaker: DANA
dialogues.text: Merry Christmas... Walter takes the package and begins to remove the wrappin paper. Inside is a COMIC BOOK. He pulls it out of the wrapping.. and on the cover is an illustration of a DARK FIGURE walk upon a RED DESERT SURFACE. The title is: THE MAN FROM MARS Walter looks at the cover in awe.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: Thanks Dana. My dad is gonna love this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norma and Arthur are now seated around a table with both of parents. Bev is running her hand through Arthur’s long hair.

dialogues.speaker: BEV
dialogues.text: When are you gonna cut this hair?

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: Never.

dialogues.speaker: BEV
dialogues.text: (to Norma) Are you still cutting his hair?

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: Uh-huh. ARTHUR SR. Are you Leonard or Skynard?

dialogues.speaker: BEV
dialogues.text: Well honey... they’re never gonna let you into outer space with these sideburns.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: They're all wearing them that way now, Bev.  35. NATHAN BURNS (26), Norma's wheelchair-bound younger broth comes rolling up.

dialogues.speaker: NATHAN
dialogues.text: Quter space? Is someone planning on departing the surface of the earth?

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: Nathan! Arthur stands up and gives him a hug.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It's been years. How have you been?

dialogues.speaker: NATHAN
dialogues.text: I've been better... I mean, I used to have legs... The table goes silent... Susan looks as though she might start to cry.

dialogues.speaker: NATHAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Sorry... morbid humor. What’s this talk about outer space?

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: Arthur has been working at Nasa.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: He helped design the camera that photographed the Mars surface. Arthur puts his hands on the back of Nathan's wheelchair.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: Nathan and I are gonna go grab a drink... He begins to wheel Nathan toward the bar.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: Arthur made me a new prosthesis for my foot. Some space age formula... it’s incredible.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: Can he make Nathan a pair of prosthetic legs?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur now sits with Nathan over by the bar.  36.

dialogues.speaker: NATHAN
dialogues.text: Can you believe it? I survive eighteen months crawling through the Vietnam jungle ... and not one bullet so much as grazes my body. (beat) And I come home, taxe a few tabs of LSD at a Grateful Dead show and wrap my car around a tree. Arthur doesn’t know how to respond.

dialogues.speaker: NATHAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Pretty damn sad... losing the legs that way, but I always thought it was Karmic retribution for what I did to Norma.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: What’d you ever do to Norma?

dialogues.speaker: NATHAN
dialogues.text: I dropped that barb211 on her foot when we were kids. That’s why she went to get that x-ray. If it wasn’t for me... she'd still have all her toes.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: You can’t think of it that way.

dialogues.speaker: NATHAN
dialogues.text: Why not? It’s the truth.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: you didn’t leave the x-ray machine on, Dr. Stupid did.

dialogues.speaker: NATHAN
dialogues.text: Yeah, but my mistake sent her to Dr. Stupid... so that makes me culpable in the eyes of Buddha.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: You're no more culpable than the company that manufactured the barbell. Stop punishing yourself. Nathan smiles in appreciation and takes a long swig of Ja Daniels.

dialogues.speaker: NATHAN
dialogues.text: You know he's here.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: Who?  37.

dialogues.speaker: NATHAN
dialogues.text: Dr. Stupid. Nathan nods his head across the room... where DR. EARL ST (50s) is seated at a table with his wife.

dialogues.speaker: NATHAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Dr. Earl Stupe. He’s still got a practice over on the west end. Arthur looks over at him... for a moment they make brief contact... and Stupe quickly looks away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Susan is now staring at Dr. Stupe. They are joined by DEB BURNS (24), Norma’s younger sister and bride-to-be.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: I wonder if he even recognizes us.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: I’m sure he does.

dialogues.speaker: DEBORAH
dialogues.text: I can’t believe they still let him practice medicine.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: You gotta let it go. You gotta learn to forgive and forget.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: I'd be willing to forgive him if he would’ve just admitted his negligence under oath. The bastard lied... said it was the x-ray machine that malfunctioned. SENATOR GRIFFITH POWELL (50s) and his son EDWARD POWELL (20s), approach. Edward is the husband-to-be.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Well Senator! You look very spiffy tonight!

dialogues.speaker: POWELL
dialogues.text: Now that the mid-term elections are over... the smile lines are starting to fade. Powell puts on a fake smile, grabs Jim’s hand and they bo wave... poking fun at politician behavior.  38.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Well... we all voted! Powell looks over at Norma.

dialogues.speaker: POWELL
dialogues.text: Norma... right?

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: That's right. He shakes her hand... fascinated by her,

dialogues.speaker: POWELL
dialogues.text: And you’re married to the aspiring astronaut.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: That's right. There he is right over there. She points over to Arthur the bar. Powell looks over at him... and they briefly make eye contact.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dana and Walter are sitting on the floor, playing MONOPOL

dialogues.speaker: DANA
dialogues.text: Walter?

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: DANA
dialogues.text: Will you take me down to the basement? I want to see your dad’s darkroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dana and Walter come down the stairs into the BASEMENT of house. RED LIGHT envelops the room. There are two long wo WORK BENCHES running down the middle. There are a series of BLACK AND WHITE PHOTOGRAPHS hanging from a wire. Each one shows a different view of the surfa of MARS.

dialogues.speaker: DANA
dialogues.text: Is that Mars?

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: Yep.  39.

dialogues.speaker: DANA
dialogues.text: What did your dad have to do with the Viking?

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: He helped design the camera. Walter points to a PLASTIC PROTOTYPE MODEL of the VIKING LANDER mounted on a third WORK BENCH at the end of the ro A model of the MARS SURFACE has been re-created and paint with exacting detail.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: He’s making the model for the science museum. Walter points to one of TWO CAMERAS mounted on the front the SPIDER-SHAPED LANDING MODULE. The camera is cylindric and features a VERTICAL SLOT on the front.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: They designed the camera to photograph in 360 degrees. It scans in the image one line at a time... and takes about five minutes to complete one revolution. DANA. How do they get the images back to earth?

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: Radio transmission. They figured out a way to interpret the scan lines and then print them onto film.

dialogues.speaker: DANA
dialogues.text: How long does it take to transmit back to earth?

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: About ten hours. Dana looks over at the wall and sees a NEW YORK TIMES FRO PAGE from September with a large image of MARS on it.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: They tested the camera in the parking lot at Langley last year. Walter points to another FRAMED PHOTOGRAPH on the wall. They see a AMBULANCE pass down the main street of the campus with it sirens on. Cahill emerges from inside the building and rushes out to parking lot. Bevilacqua and the others are approaching.

dialogues.speaker: CAHILL
dialogues.text: What happened?

dialogues.speaker: BEVILACQUA
dialogues.text: The module got hit!

dialogues.speaker: CAHILL
dialogues.text: Lightning?

dialogues.speaker: BEVILACQUA
dialogues.text: Yeah. Steward was up there on the trestle. He got burned real bad! The CAMERA moves in toward Bevilacqua’s face... his eyes filled with anguish and despair.  61.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: gim Burns stands in front of a group of POLICE OFFICERS i briefing room. He holds up a large FAMILY PHOTO of ROBERT BEVILACQUA, posing with his WIFE and YOUNG DAUGHTER.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: Our fugitive is named Robert Bevilacqua. He shot and killed his wife at their residence on Cary Street earlier today. We believe that he escaped on foot... and could be armed and dangerous. The CAMERA moves across a line of POLICE OFFICERS... listening...

dialogues.speaker: JIM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Mr. Bevilacqua is an employee at NASA... and he is a former Marine who served in Vietnam. He may very well be armed and dangerous...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The CAMERA tracks through a dingy RICHMOND DIVE BAR. Bevilacqua sits at the bar with a baseball cap pulled dow low to conceal his face. He is drinking whiskey. Wendell James approaches... carrying a FILE under his arm

dialogues.speaker: WENDELL
dialogues.text: Bevilacqua... Bevilacqua turns to face him

dialogues.speaker: BEVILACQUA
dialogues.text: Wendell. They hug one another.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two men are now sitting across from one another in a BOOTH. Wendell has a NASA BLUE-PRINT laid out on the tabl The blue-print is of the button unit.

dialogues.speaker: BEVILACCQUA
dialogues.text: You designed it?

dialogues.speaker: WENDELL
dialogues.text: Yeah. Cahill told me to...  62. Bevilacqua notices a SMALL PURPLE STAIN on the blue-print

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.speaker: WENDELL
dialogues.text: This what you were looking for, sir? Cahill looks stares at the blue-print... possessed. A DRO BLOOD falls from his right nostril and lands on it.

dialogues.speaker: CAHILL
dialogues.text: Yes, Thank you Wendell.

dialogues.speaker: CAHILL
dialogues.text: You're not gonna hurt these boys, are you?

dialogues.text: Any harm that comes to them will be their own doing. Arlington takes the bag and moves toward the hangar entra EXT. dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wendell then hands a file to Bevilacqua. Inside there is dossier and photo of a ARTHUR LEWIS. He flips to another dossier and photo of another NASA EMPLOYEE named KENNETH WELLER.

dialogues.speaker: WENDELL
dialogues.text: There's a list... and they’ve all got a wife and one child. Bevilacgua thumbs through the list of NASA dossiers. He s Arthur Lewis among them.

dialogues.speaker: WENDELL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Did you kill your wife? Bevilacqua just stares at him... on the verge of tears. H slides an ENVELOPE across the table.

dialogues.speaker: BEVILACQUA
dialogues.text: This is a confession letter that I wrote... it explains everything that happened with Steward and the box. Keep it... cause if I don’t make it... this might clear my name one day. Bevilacqua looks at the KENNETH WELLER dossier.

dialogues.speaker: BEVILACQUA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: This guy Weller is gonna be next. Did you get their phone number?

dialogues.speaker: WENDELL
dialogues.text: No. They’re not listed. Just an old address south of Petersburg. What are you gonna do?

dialogues.speaker: BEVILACQUA
dialogues.text: I don’t know. I need a car. I might be able to save them... and this guy Arthur Lewis... Wendell thinks to himself... then retrieves a set of KEYS from his pocket.

dialogues.speaker: WENDELL
dialogues.text: These are the keys to my cousin's pick-up truck. It’s not registered. It’s parked in front of my house over on Byrd street. Take it...

dialogues.speaker: BEVILACQUA
dialogues.text: Thank you, Wendell.  64. INT, RICHMOND POLICE STATION -- BURNS’S OFFICE -- LATER Burns sits behind his desk... telephone to his ear.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: (into phone) Steward. First name Arlington... middie name is James. He begins to scrawl words down on a piece of paper:

dialogues.text: Sir... there’s a Mr. Steward here to see you.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: (into phone) Thank you... that’s all I need. He hangs up the phone and looks through the glass window his office into the reception area. Standing there through the glass... is a man who looks identical to Arlington Steward. He stands with the normal side of his face in profile, He turns to face Jim... but his face now appears as it did before he was burned. Is this the same person? Jim turns to his receptionist... who waits in the doorway

dialogues.speaker: JIM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Send him in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.text: The real Arlington Steward is now standing in the periodi area.of the library... situated in front of the circulati desk. He stands in profile... then turns toward the CAMERA in t same manner aS his TWIN in the police station. His burned face forms a deformed smile... INT. RICHMOND POLICE STATION -- BURNS’S OFFICE -- NEXT The STEWARD TWIN steps into Jim’s office. He reaches out shakes Jim’s hand.

dialogues.speaker: STEWARD TWIN
dialogues.text: officer Burns... my name is Reston Steward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arlington... with his eyes closed... mimics his TWIN’S movement exactly... reaching out his hand and shaking it nothing.

dialogues.speaker: ARLINGTON
dialogues.text: Officer Burns... my name is Reston Steward. INT. RICHMOND POLICE STATION -- BURNS’S OFFICE -- NEXT RESTON STEWARD (40) sits down in the chair across from hi desk.

dialogues.speaker: RESTON
dialogues.text: I see you have made an inquiry about my brother Arlington.

dialogues.speaker: INT, RICHMOND PUBLIC LIBRARY
dialogues.text: Arlington is now seated in a library chair... eyes closed in the exact same manner as his brother. It is as though is controlling his twin brother's body via remote telepat

dialogues.speaker: ARLINGTON
dialogues.text: ...an inguiry about my brother Arlington.  66. INT. RICHMOND POLICE STATION -- BURNS’S OFFICE -- NEXT Jim stares at him from across his desk.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: Yes. Apparently he made an appearance at my daughter’s house. Your brother works for NASA?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arlington nods his head.

dialogues.speaker: ARLINGTON
dialogues.text: Yes. My brother works at the Langley research facility. INT. RICHMOND POLICE STATION -- BURNS’S OFFICE -- NEXT Jim nods his head in return.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: With my son-in-law.

dialogues.speaker: RESTON
dialogues.text: That's right.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: And may I ask... what do you do, Mr. Steward?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With his eyes closed... Arlington reaches into his pocket retrieves something imaginary from his pocket. He raises something that we cannot see up into the air. INT, RICHMOND POLICE STATION -- BURNS’S OFFICE -- NEXT Reston is now holding out a GOVERNMENT BADGE with his rig hand.

dialogues.speaker: RESTON
dialogues.text: I work for the CIA.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: I see. He then hands Jim one of his cards. Jim looks at it.  67.

dialogues.speaker: RESTON STEWARD
dialogues.text: Reston rises to his feet... putting his hat on his head.

dialogues.speaker: RESTON
dialogues.text: I assure you my brother is of no threat to your daughter. However, the man you're locking for... Robert Bevilacqua. He is very dangerous... and ke might try and contact your son-in-law or your daughter.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: Really.

dialogues.speaker: RESTON
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: RESTON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Help us find Bevilacqua. If and when you do... please call us. Jim stares at the business card as Reston bids him good-b

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arlington is now standing. With his eyes still closed, he nods his head and smiles, then turns and begins to walk several steps. He then stops... takes a deep breath... an opens his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reston opens his eyes... as if a spirit has suddenly left body. He takes a deep breath and smiles at the Receptioni trying to conceal his expression of horror. He moves toward the exit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reston emerges from the General Assembly building. There plack town car waiting. A CIA AGENT stands next to it. Reston withdraws a HANDKERCHIEF and wipes BLOOD from his nose.  68.

dialogues.speaker: RESTON
dialogues.text: General Nathan Teague at the Pentagon. Get him cn the phone immediately. The Agent opens the car door, and Reston steps inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norma and Arthur are still sitting in front of the microf machine. Norma looks like she is going to faint... her fa has gone white. ° ARTHUR You alright, Norma?

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: I feel like I’m gonna faint... She stands up to leave.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: Where are you going?

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: Bathroom. Norma moves, toward the main library... leaving Arthur al

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norma emerges from the records room and walks toward the circulation desk. As she rounds the corner... Arlington emerges from behind a row of book shelves. Norma stops in her tracks... frozen. He stares her down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur stares at the microfiche reader... transfixed by t newspaper articles. A shadow passes across the wall... and Arthur senses some lurking over his shoulder. He turns to see that it is the LIBRARIAN. Something about her is different... she seems possessed.

dialogues.speaker: LIBRARIAN
dialogues.text: The myth of Prometheus tells the story of a God who created man. (beat) (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: LIBRARIAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: When Prometheus flew too close to the sun... his wings caught fire... and he fell to the earth. Arthur remembers her voice from the phone call.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: Was that you on the phone? You‘’re his mother...

dialogues.speaker: LIBRARIAN
dialogues.text: He finds your wife fascinating... Mr. Lewis. Her name is ELIZABETH STEWARD.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norma remains frozen... her mind racing. Arlington smiles her... gesturing toward an empty chair.

dialogues.speaker: ARLINGTON
dialogues.text: Have a seat... Mrs. Lewis. She looks around... realizing that the library is now completely empty.

dialogues.speaker: ARLINGTON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Don't be afraid. I may look like a monster... but’I can’ assure you that I am... only human. His face contorts into a broad smile.

dialogues.speaker: ARLINGTON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Please... sit down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elizabeth sits down on the chair across from Arthur.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: My name is Clymene, mother of five. Prometheus, Atlas, Menoetius, Logan, and Epimetheus. A drop of blood begins to ooze from her left eye as she speaks.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Epimetheus is the twin brother of Prometheus, but he has become his brother's slave... the victim of his cunning and deceit.  70.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norma is now seated in a chair across from him. He stares deep into her eyes... transfixed by her beauty.

dialogues.speaker: ARLINGTON
dialogues.text: Tell me Norma... when was the exact moment that you realized you loved your husband? There is something about him that now makes her feel safe willing to tell him anything.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: About five seconds after I laid eyes on him.

dialogues.speaker: ARLINGTON
dialogues.text: And when was this?

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: In college. My sophomore year. He was a year younger than me. We dated for two weeks and then... She stops herself.

dialogues.speaker: ARLINGTON
dialogues.text: You became frightened about something.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: Then I thought... this is too good to be true. When he sees my mangled foot... he’s gonna be out the door in ten seconds and he’s gonna go tell all his friends.

dialogues.speaker: ARLINGTON
dialogues.text: How did he respond when you showed him?

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: We were at the drive-in... and he caught a glimpse of the scars on my thigh. He asked me what happened... and I felt this sense of dread. wh ARLINGTON Ly?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because you can just see the glow disappear in someone's eyes when they discover something about you that they just can’t stomach.

dialogues.speaker: ARLINGTON
dialogues.text: Did the glow disappear from his eyes?

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: No. Not Arthur. He was different than the others. He... said that... my scars were cool. (beat) He said that they made me more attractive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur sits across from Elizabeth. His mind is racing... trying to put the puzzle pieces together. He looks at his watch. It is almost 5PM.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: I have worked at this library for forty years. Since 1936, I have read a book a day. 23455 books I have read.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: wow. (beat) Someone should nominate you for librarian of the year. She holds the copy of No Exit in her hands.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Of all of the books I have read in my lifetime... this is my son’s favorite. (beat) Have you ever read No Exit?

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: No. She reaches out with her hand.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Take my hand... and I'll show you.  72. He stares at the blood coagulating in the bag beneath her left eye.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: I’m not gonna touch you, lady.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arlington now stares directly into Norma’s soul. The scar tissue on the left side of his face does not mov when he smiles. It remains frozen... unable to express emotion.

dialogues.speaker: ARLINGTON
dialogues.text: And what emotion did you feel when you first laid eyes upon me, Norma? She thinks silently for a moment. NORMA. I felt... She stops herself... afraid of how he might respond if sh honest with him.

dialogues.speaker: ARLINGTON
dialogues.text: You felt what?

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: I felt...

dialogues.speaker: ARLINGTON
dialogues.text: Pity?

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: Love.

dialogues.speaker: ARLINGTON
dialogues.text: You felt love for me?

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: ARLINGTON
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: Because of my foot. Because of my disfigurement. I thought of all the pain I've felt in my life because of it... the physical pain... the emotional pain. (beat) (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: NORMA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I thought about what it would be like to have that pain magnified and projected onto my face... onto a part of my body that I can’t hide with a shoe. There are tears welling in her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I saw all of that pain in your face and I understood it... and I felt an overwhelming feeling of love for you because I knew I’d never feel sorry for myself or my goddamn foot ever again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elizabeth continues to hold her hand out toward Arthur.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Take my hand, son.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: You called me a cuckold. You made a statement... made an implication to me that my wife was going to be killed. (beat) So please understand why I might be reluctant to take your hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arlington reaches his hand out to Norma.

dialogues.speaker: ARLINGTON
dialogues.text: Take my hand, Norma... She stares at him, unable to move... then takes his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elizabeth reaches out and grabs Arthur’s hand against his will. His body convulses at her touch... The CAMERA drifts in toward Arthur’s face as his eyes slo close. Her spell has been cast upon him.. cur TO BLACK: SILENCE.  74.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: Norma... Her eyes open. She looks around... disoriented.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Norma... what happened? NORMA. I don't know. Norma notices Walter standing in the doorway.

dialogues.text: You came home an hour ago.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: We did? She sits up in bed... looking at the clock radio. It is 6

dialogues.text: Neither of you said a word... you just walked into the house like two zombies. Went straight to bed. Arthur and Norma stare at one another, trying to make sen of what has just transpired.

dialogues.speaker: NORMA
dialogues.text: The wedding. It starts in an hour. We've got to get ready.  76. Norma sees that the copy of No Exit is now sitting on the bedside table.

LEWIS HOUSE -- WALTER’S BEDROOM -- NEXT Arthur sits on the end of Walter’s bed. Walters stands in front of him as his father ties his NECK TIE in front of standing mirror.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: What’s going on?

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: This is about the box... isn’t it?

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: Did you push the button?

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: Your mother did.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: What happens when you push the button?  77.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: I don’t know.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: Where did you get this?

dialogues.text: Dana. She gave it to me. Arthur begins to page through the comic book.

dialogues.text: Alright... they are entering the building from the south entrance on fourteenth street.

dialogues.text: Excuse me... may I help you?

dialogues.speaker: ARLINGTON
dialogues.text: Where is he?

dialogues.speaker: RECEPTIONIST
dialogues.text: Uhhh... he’s in a meeting.

dialogues.speaker: ARLINGTON
dialogues.text: I need to see him... now. INT. GRIFFITH POWELL’S OFFICE -- NEXT The RECEPTIONIST comes into the office. Griffith Powell stands at the window behind tis desk... smoking a cigaret He is dressed in a TUXEDO with his jacket hanging next to desk.  72.

dialogues.speaker: RECEPTIONIST
dialogues.text: He’s here... I don’t know what to do. Powell turns to face her.

dialogues.speaker: POWELL
dialogues.text: Let him in. The Receptionist goes back out... and within moments... Arlington and Bud enter the office. The Receptionist clos the door and leaves them alore.

dialogues.speaker: ARLINGTON
dialogues.text: Hello Senator.

dialogues.speaker: POWELL
dialogues.text: (terrified) Mr. Steward... it’s good to see you.

dialogues.speaker: ARLINGTON
dialogues.text: Call me Arlington.

dialogues.speaker: POWELL
dialogues.text: Okay... Arlington. Bud just stares at the Senator... showing no sign of emot
